title: Frijoles Charros with Rice
description: Hearty Mexican-style cowboy beans simmered with smoky bacon, onion, tomato, chiles and fresh cilantro, served alongside steamed white rice. Robust, savory, and slightly spicy, this one-pot bean stew is quick to finish when using canned beans or can be cooked from dry beans for deeper flavor.

ingredients.display_name: dried pinto beans (soaked) or canned pinto beans, drained and rinsed
ingredients.notes: If using dried, soak overnight and cook until tender; canned is pre-cooked

ingredients.display_name: jalapeño, seeded and minced (adjust to taste)
roma tomatoes, diced (or 1 can diced tomatoes, drained)

ingredients.notes: can substitute vegetable broth for vegetarian version (not strictly supported)
for simmering beans and adjusting consistency
use oil if reducing saturated fat

ingredients.display_name: dried Mexican oregano or regular oregano

ingredients.notes: adjust to taste, especially if using salted broth

steps.text: If using dried beans, soak overnight, drain, rinse and simmer until tender (see note); if using canned beans, drain and rinse them and set aside.

Start the rice: rinse rice until water runs clear, combine with measured water and a pinch of salt in a saucepan, bring to a boil, reduce to low, cover and simmer until water is absorbed and rice is tender.

While rice cooks, heat a large heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat and add the diced bacon; cook, stirring occasionally, until fat renders and bacon is crisp and golden. Remove some bacon if excessive fat remains, leaving about 1 tbsp in the pot.
Add oil if needed and sauté chopped onion in the bacon fat over medium heat until translucent, about until edges soften, then add minced garlic and minced jalapeño and cook briefly until fragrant.
Stir in diced tomatoes and cook down 2-3 minutes to concentrate flavor, then add ground cumin, oregano, smoked paprika if using, salt and pepper; sauté to bloom the spices.
Add drained beans, chicken broth and water to the pot, scraping up any browned bits; bring to a gentle simmer, reduce heat and simmer uncovered to meld flavors and reduce slightly.
Taste and adjust seasoning with salt, pepper and more cumin if desired; fold in most of the reserved crisped bacon, leaving some for garnish.
Finish by stirring in chopped cilantro and a squeeze of lime juice if desired, then remove from heat and let rest a few minutes to allow flavors to settle.
Serve fragrant frijoles charros ladled over or alongside steamed rice, garnish with remaining bacon, extra cilantro and lime wedges.
